cta_structure.title: Tibetan Supreme Justice Commission (TSJC)
cta_structure.short_description: The highest judicial authority of the Central Tibetan Administration, responsible for upholding the rule of law and ensuring justice.
cta_structure.long_description: The Tibetan Supreme Justice Commission (TSJC) is the highest judicial authority of the Central Tibetan Administration. It is responsible for upholding the rule of law, interpreting Tibetan laws, and ensuring justice within the Tibetan exile community. Functioning independently from the executive (Kashag) and legislative (Parliament) branches, the TSJC safeguards judicial independence and ensures that legal processes remain fair, impartial, and consistent with democratic principles and Tibetan values.

subsections.title: Justice Secretariat
subsections.content: The Justice Secretariat serves as the administrative and operational backbone of the TSJC. It supports the Commission by managing case documentation, coordinating hearings, maintaining judicial records, and facilitating communication between different justice bodies under the Tibetan judicial system. The Secretariat ensures the smooth functioning of the courts and assists in implementing judicial decisions.

subsections.title: Tibetan Circuit Justice Commission (TCJC)
subsections.content: The TCJC operates as a mobile judicial body under the TSJC. Its primary role is to bring justice closer to Tibetan communities by conducting hearings directly in settlements and regions that are geographically distant from the central judiciary. This system ensures access to justice for all Tibetans in exile, regardless of location, and helps resolve civil disputes in a timely and accessible manner.

details.title: TCJC – Dekyiling
details.content: The TCJC at Dekyiling functions as a regional base for circuit justice activities in North India. From this location, the Circuit Justice Commission conducts hearings and judicial proceedings for nearby Tibetan settlements, reducing the burden on litigants who would otherwise need to travel long distances for legal redress.

subsections.title: Tibetan Local Justice Commission (TLJC)
subsections.content: The Tibetan Local Justice Commission (TLJC) handles minor civil disputes, mediation, and community-level legal matters. Emphasizing reconciliation and amicable settlement, the TLJC plays an important role in maintaining harmony within Tibetan communities by resolving conflicts at the grassroots level, often using mediation informed by Tibetan customary practices.

details.title: Northern Region (Dekyiling)
details.content: The Northern Region TLJC, based in Dekyiling, serves Tibetan settlements across North India. It addresses local disputes and minor legal cases, providing accessible justice and mediation services within the community.

details.title: Southern Region (Bylakuppe)
details.content: The Southern Region TLJC, located in Bylakuppe, caters to one of the largest Tibetan settlement areas in South India. It plays a crucial role in resolving community disputes and maintaining social harmony among a large resident population.

details.title: Ladakh Region
details.content: The TLJC in Ladakh serves Tibetan communities living in the Ladakh region. It addresses local justice needs while taking into account the unique geographic, cultural, and social context of Tibetans living in this high-altitude border region.

cta_structure.title: Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile (TPiE)
cta_structure.short_description: The unicameral legislative body and highest representative institution representing Tibetans globally.
cta_structure.long_description:
The Tibetan Parliament-in Exile (TPiE) is the unicameral legislative body and highest representative institution of the Central Tibetan Administration (CTA)—the democratically elected government of Tibetans living in exile. It embodies the democratic aspirations of the global Tibetan community and functions as a central pillar of Tibetan governance alongside the Judiciary and Executive.

Established as part of the democratic structures developed by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama, the Tibetan Parliament in Exile evolved from early representative bodies into a fully modern legislature. Democratic governance in exile began soon after the Tibetan government was reconstituted in India following the 1959 uprising and subsequent exile, with formal legislative powers progressively strengthened through the Charter of the Tibetans in Exile.

subsections.title: Location and Significance
subsections.content: The Parliament sits in Dharamshala, India, in the foothills of the Himalayas, a place often referred to as 'Little Lhasa'. Its position in exile underscores both the ongoing Tibetan struggle for freedom and the resilience of its democratic institutions.

subsections.title: Composition and Representation
subsections.content: The 17th Tibetan Parliament in Exile comprises 45 members from across the Tibetan diaspora. Representatives include ten members each from the three traditional provinces of Tibet (Ü-Tsang, Kham, and Amdo), members from the four major schools of Tibetan Buddhism and the Bon religion, and representatives of Tibetans living in North America, Europe, Australasia, and other regions. This structure ensures both cultural diversity and geographic representation within the legislature.

subsections.title: Leadership and Electoral Process
subsections.content: Parliamentarians elect among themselves a Speaker and Deputy Speaker to preside over sessions. Elections are held every five years, with all Tibetans in exile aged 18 and above eligible to vote and those aged 25 and above eligible to contest. Sessions are typically convened bi-annually.

subsections.title: Functions and Role
subsections.content: The TPiE has several key responsibilities within the Central Tibetan Administration:

details.title: Legislative Authority
details.content: To enact laws, frame rules and regulations, and amend policies in accordance with the Charter of the Tibetans in Exile.

details.title: Oversight
details.content: To supervise the administration's finances and public expenditure.

details.title: Advocacy and Liaison
details.content: To engage with governments, parliaments, NGOs and civil society worldwide to garner support for the Tibetan cause and international advocacy.

details.title: Representation
details.content: To bring the concerns and aspirations of the global Tibetan diaspora into policy debates at the highest level.

subsections.title: Democratic Resilience & Engagement
subsections.content: Despite operating in exile, the Tibetan Parliament continues to uphold democratic norms and processes, reflecting the enduring commitment of the Tibetan people to self-governance, freedom, and non-violent advocacy. Its activities extend beyond law-making to include cultural preservation, community outreach, and international diplomacy.

subsections.title: Parliamentary Secretariat
subsections.content: The Parliament Secretariat is the administrative and operational backbone of the TPiE, responsible for ensuring the smooth functioning, continuity, and institutional integrity of the Parliament. While the MPs serve as elected representatives, the Secretariat provides the professional, non-partisan support that enables Parliament to discharge its constitutional and democratic responsibilities effectively.

details.title: Role and Mandate
details.content: Functions as the permanent administrative body of the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, assisting in its legislative, oversight, and representative functions in accordance with the Charter.

details.title: Legislative Support
details.content: Organizes parliamentary sessions, prepares agendas, records proceedings, and maintains official transcripts and resolutions.

details.title: Documentation
details.content: Maintains laws passed, debates, and archival records, serving as the democratic memory of the Tibetan people in exile.

details.title: Liaison
details.content: Acts as a bridge between MPs, CTA departments, and external stakeholders, coordinating delegations and international outreach.

details.title: Structure
details.content: Operates under the Speaker, headed by a Secretary-level official and staffed by neutral, professional civil servants.

subsections.title: Local Tibetan Assemblies (40 Locations)
subsections.content: Grassroots democratic institutions functioning as the local representative bodies of the Tibetan people in exile, ensuring democratic participation extends beyond Dharamshala to settlements across India.

subsections.title: Freedom Movement Sub-Committees (BRDL)
subsections.content: Functioning globally in 148 locations, these committees mobilize Tibetans and supporters for advocacy, awareness, and democratic engagement. They also support the grassroots collection of the Tibetan Chatrel contributions.

cta_structure.title: Kashag (Cabinet)
cta_structure.short_description: The executive branch of the CTA, responsible for day-to-day governance and administration of the Tibetan community in exile.
cta_structure.long_description:
The Kashag is the executive branch of the Central Tibetan Administration and is responsible for the day-to-day governance and administration of the Tibetan community in exile. It is headed by the Sikyong, who serves as the political leader and head of the executive. The Kashag consists of seven Kalons (Cabinet Ministers), each responsible for overseeing one or more CTA departments.

The Sikyong is democratically elected by Tibetans in exile for a five-year term. The most recent Sikyong election was held in 2021, and the next election cycle is scheduled for 2026. As head of the executive, the Sikyong provides overall leadership, policy direction, and representation of the Tibetan people at national and international levels.

After assuming office, the Sikyong nominates the seven Kalons, selecting individuals based on experience, expertise, and suitability for ministerial responsibility. These nominations are then presented to the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile for approval. Each nominated Kalon must receive a majority vote in Parliament to be formally appointed. This process ensures democratic oversight of the executive, balances executive authority with legislative scrutiny, and reinforces accountability within the Tibetan democratic system.

The Kashag functions collectively, with decisions taken through consultation and shared responsibility. It is accountable to the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile and can be questioned, reviewed, or held responsible through parliamentary procedures, reflecting the checks and balances built into Tibetan democratic governance.

subsections.title: Kashag Secretariat
subsections.content: The Kashag Secretariat is the central administrative unit that supports the functioning of the executive branch. It assists the Kashag by managing official correspondence, preparing agendas and documentation for cabinet meetings, recording decisions, and coordinating follow-up actions across CTA departments. The Secretariat plays a critical role in ensuring continuity, coordination, and effective implementation of executive policies, and serves as the primary institutional link between the Kashag, Parliament, and other constitutional bodies.

departments.title: Department of Religion and Culture
departments.content: The Department of Religion and Culture is one of the key departments under the Kashag of the Central Tibetan Administration. Its primary responsibility is to preserve, protect, and promote Tibetan religion, culture, language, and identity in exile. The department works to ensure the continuity of Tibetan Buddhist traditions, cultural practices, and scholarly heritage while also adapting them to contemporary global contexts. It provides policy guidance, administrative support, and coordination for monasteries, nunneries, and cultural institutions affiliated with the CTA.

subsections.title: Monasteries (259)
subsections.content: The department oversees and supports 259 Tibetan monasteries in exile, which serve as spiritual, educational, and cultural centers for the Tibetan community. These monasteries play a central role in preserving Buddhist philosophy, monastic discipline, ritual practices, and traditional learning systems that have been passed down for centuries.

subsections.title: Nunneries (36)
subsections.content: There are 36 nunneries under the department’s purview, dedicated to the religious education, spiritual development, and empowerment of Tibetan nuns. In recent decades, these nunneries have also become important centers for advancing educational opportunities and leadership roles for women within Tibetan religious life.

subsections.title: Cultural Institutions
subsections.content:
The Department of Religion and Culture supports several major cultural and academic institutions that safeguard Tibetan heritage and promote it globally. These institutions include bodies dedicated to performing arts, higher education, archives, traditional arts and crafts, and cultural research. Through these institutions, the department ensures that Tibetan culture remains a living tradition rather than a static legacy.

Key institutions under the department include:

details.title: Tibetan Institute of Performing Arts (TIPA)
details.content: Dedicated to preserving and promoting traditional Tibetan music, dance, and opera.

details.title: Tibet House Society
details.content: Promoting Tibetan culture and scholarship internationally.

details.title: Central University of Tibetan Studies (CUTS)
details.content: A center for higher education in Tibetan and Buddhist studies.

details.title: Library of Tibetan Works and Archives (LTWA)
details.content: A major repository of Tibetan texts, manuscripts, and historical records.

details.title: Norbulingka Institute
details.content: Preserving Tibetan arts, crafts, and cultural education.

details.title: Manjushree Center of Tibetan Culture
details.content: Promoting Tibetan cultural learning and awareness.

departments.title: Department of Home
departments.content: The Department of Home is one of the largest and most people-facing departments under the Kashag of the Central Tibetan Administration. It is responsible for the administration, welfare, rehabilitation, and socio-economic development of Tibetan communities in exile. The department works closely with Tibetan settlements across India, Nepal, and Bhutan to support livelihoods, community infrastructure, social welfare services, and overall settlement governance. In many ways, it acts as the primary link between the CTA and the everyday lives of Tibetans in exile.

subsections.title: Tibetan Settlement Offices (TSO)
subsections.content: The Department of Home oversees Tibetan Settlement Offices (TSOs), which function as local administrative units within Tibetan settlements. TSOs implement CTA policies at the ground level, manage settlement affairs, coordinate welfare and development programs, and serve as the first point of contact between the community and the central administration.

details.title: India
details.content: 36 TSOs

details.title: Nepal
details.content: 7 TSOs

details.title: Bhutan
details.content: 1 TSO

subsections.title: Agricultural Section
subsections.content: The Agricultural Section supports farming-based livelihoods within Tibetan settlements. It works to improve agricultural productivity, promote sustainable practices, and strengthen food security for settlement communities that depend on agriculture as a primary source of income.

subsections.title: Welfare Section
subsections.content: The Welfare Section focuses on social protection and community well-being. It supports vulnerable groups, coordinates assistance programs, and ensures that basic welfare needs of the Tibetan population—especially those facing hardship—are addressed.

subsections.title: Real Estate Section
subsections.content: The Real Estate Section manages land, housing, and property-related matters within Tibetan settlements. It plays a crucial role in safeguarding settlement assets and ensuring proper use and maintenance of community property.

subsections.title: Old Age Homes
subsections.content: The Department of Home oversees Old Age Homes that provide care, shelter, and support to elderly Tibetans who may not have family support. These facilities ensure dignity, care, and security for senior members of the community.

subsections.title: Baby Crèches
subsections.content: Baby Crèches under the Department of Home provide early childhood care and support for young children, particularly in settlements where parents are engaged in work. These centers contribute to child welfare and early development while supporting working families.

departments.title: Department of Finance
departments.content: The Department of Finance is responsible for managing the financial administration, revenue systems, budgeting, and development financing of the Central Tibetan Administration. It plays a central role in ensuring financial sustainability, transparency, and accountability across CTA institutions and programs. The department oversees public funds, community contribution systems, development finance mechanisms, and capacity-building initiatives that support long-term self-reliance of the Tibetan community in exile.

subsections.title: Budget Section
subsections.content: The Budget Section prepares, allocates, and monitors the annual CTA budget. It coordinates with all departments and offices to ensure that public funds are used efficiently and in line with approved priorities, and that expenditures follow established financial rules and procedures.

subsections.title: Green Book Section
subsections.content: The Green Book Section is responsible for the issuance, registration, and maintenance of Tibetan Green Books. The Green Book serves as an official record of an individual Tibetan’s civic status and participation in the Tibetan democratic and freedom movement. This section manages Green Book documentation, records, renewals, and verification, ensuring that each registered Tibetan has an official and traceable Green Book identity within the CTA system.

subsections.title: Chatrel Section
subsections.content: The Chatrel Section is responsible for collecting Green Book contributions from Tibetans in exile. These contributions are voluntary but strongly encouraged as a form of civic responsibility and support for the Tibetan freedom struggle and the functioning of the CTA. The Chatrel Section records contributions, issues receipts, and coordinates with settlement offices and other collection points to ensure proper accounting and transparency.

subsections.title: Women Empowerment Desk
subsections.content: The Women Empowerment Desk works to strengthen the economic and institutional participation of Tibetan women. It supports initiatives focused on financial inclusion, skills development, and empowerment of women within the community.

subsections.title: Tibetan Computer Resource Center (TCRC)
subsections.content: The Tibetan Computer Resource Center (TCRC) focuses on building digital capacity within CTA institutions and the Tibetan community. It supports ICT systems, digital literacy, and technology-driven solutions for administration and development.

subsections.title: Social and Resource Development Fund (SARD)
subsections.content: The Social and Resource Development Fund (SARD) mobilizes and manages development resources for Tibetan welfare and community projects. It works closely with donors and partners to implement programs in areas such as livelihoods, education, and social development.

details.title: Official Website
details.content: https://sardfund.org/

subsections.title: Blue Book
subsections.content: The Blue Book system records contributions made by non-Tibetans who wish to support the Tibetan cause. It provides an official mechanism for global supporters to contribute financially to Tibetan institutions and initiatives.

subsections.title: Tibet Corps
subsections.content: Tibet Corps is a volunteer and service-oriented initiative that engages Tibetan youth in community service, skill-building, and nation-building activities. It promotes civic responsibility and leadership among young Tibetans.

details.title: Official Website
details.content: https://tibetcorps.org/

subsections.title: Gangjong Development Finance (GDF)
subsections.content: Gangjong Development Finance (GDF) functions as a financial institution supporting Tibetan entrepreneurship and economic development. It provides loans and financial services to help Tibetan businesses grow and strengthen community livelihoods.

departments.title: Department of Education
departments.content: The Department of Education is responsible for the overall education system of Tibetans in exile, from primary schooling to higher education, scholarships, and student support services. Operating under the Kashag of the Central Tibetan Administration, the department works to ensure that Tibetan children and youth receive quality education that balances modern knowledge with Tibetan language, culture, and values. It plays a crucial role in shaping the future leadership, skills, and identity of the Tibetan community.

subsections.title: Academic Section
subsections.content: The Academic Section oversees curriculum planning, academic standards, and coordination with Tibetan schools and institutions. It ensures consistency and quality in teaching and learning across the Tibetan school system.

subsections.title: Traditional Academic Section
subsections.content: The Traditional Academic Section focuses on Tibetan language, literature, history, philosophy, and Buddhist studies. Its role is to preserve and strengthen traditional knowledge systems and ensure their transmission to younger generations.

subsections.title: Modern Academic Section
subsections.content: The Modern Academic Section manages subjects related to contemporary education, including science, mathematics, social sciences, and vocational learning. It ensures that Tibetan students are equipped to compete and succeed in modern educational and professional environments.

subsections.title: Scholarship Section
subsections.content: The Scholarship Section administers scholarships and financial assistance programs for Tibetan students pursuing higher education in India and abroad. It helps expand access to education and supports students based on merit, need, and strategic human resource priorities.

subsections.title: Education Council
subsections.content: The Education Council functions as an advisory and policy-guiding body on educational matters. It brings together expertise to review policies, recommend reforms, and guide the long-term direction of Tibetan education in exile.

subsections.title: Counselling Section
subsections.content: The Counselling Section provides academic, career, and psychosocial guidance to students. It supports student well-being, helps young people navigate educational and career choices, and addresses challenges related to stress, adjustment, and personal development.

subsections.title: Terminology Section
subsections.content: The Terminology Section is responsible for developing and standardizing Tibetan terminology, particularly for modern subjects and concepts. This work is essential for strengthening Tibetan as a living language capable of expressing contemporary knowledge and ideas.

departments.title: Department of Security
departments.content: The Department of Security is responsible for matters related to community security, refugee reception, legal documentation, and sensitive coordination within the Central Tibetan Administration. One of its most critical responsibilities is ensuring the security of His Holiness the Dalai Lama, including coordination related to his residence, public engagements, and travel. The department also works to safeguard the security of Tibetans living in exile and plays a discreet but important role in maintaining contact with Tibetans inside Tibet.

subsections.title: Reception Centers
subsections.content: The Department of Security operates Reception Centers that serve as the first point of contact for newly arrived Tibetans from Tibet. These centers provide temporary shelter, basic assistance, and coordination for registration, documentation, and onward rehabilitation.

details.title: Kathmandu Reception Center
details.content: Supports Tibetans arriving via Nepal and facilitates initial processing

details.title: Delhi Reception Center
details.content: Assists with transit, documentation, and coordination

details.title: Dharamshala Reception Center
details.content: Handles registration and coordination with central CTA offices

subsections.title: Administration
subsections.content: The Administration Section handles internal administrative functions of the Department of Security only. It manages departmental records, internal coordination, staffing, and implementation of security-related procedures. This section also plays a role in monitoring and addressing security-related concerns affecting Tibetans in exile, ensuring that community safety issues are addressed in coordination with relevant bodies.

subsections.title: Other Functions
subsections.content: Under its other key responsibilities, the Department of Security provides support and services related to legal identity and travel documentation for Tibetans in exile. This includes assistance with the Registration Certificate (RC), which allows Tibetans to legally reside in India as foreigners, and support for the Identity Certificate (IC), which serves as a travel document enabling Tibetans to travel outside India. Additionally, the department maintains communication and information links with Tibetans inside Tibet, handling these matters with sensitivity due to their security implications.

departments.title: Department of Information and International Relations (DIIR)
departments.content: The Department of Information and International Relations (DIIR) is responsible for public information, media engagement, international advocacy, diplomacy, and global coordination of the Central Tibetan Administration. DIIR serves as the voice of the Tibetan people to the world, communicating Tibetan perspectives on Tibet, democracy, human rights, environment, and culture. It also manages relations with governments, parliaments, international institutions, and Tibet support groups worldwide, while keeping Tibetans in exile informed about national and international developments.

subsections.title: Information Section
subsections.content: The Information Section handles news production, publications, digital communication, and public outreach. It ensures that accurate and timely information about Tibet and the CTA reaches Tibetans in exile, Tibetans inside Tibet (where possible), and the global public.

details.title: Tibet News Bureau
details.content: Produces daily news and official reports related to CTA activities, Tibetan political developments, and international Tibet-related events.

details.title: Tibetan Sheja
details.content: Publishes news and articles in Tibetan, focusing on community affairs, governance, and national issues.

details.title: Tibetan Freedom
details.content: Focuses on advocacy-related content, highlighting issues concerning Tibet’s political status, human rights, and freedom movement.

details.title: English Tibetan Bulletin
details.content: Provides English-language updates, making Tibetan issues accessible to international audiences, researchers, policymakers, and supporters.

details.title: Website
details.content: DIIR manages the official CTA website, which serves as a central platform for news, documents, statements, and public information.

details.title: China Desk
details.content: Monitors political, social, and policy developments related to Tibet inside the People’s Republic of China and provides analysis and information relevant to advocacy and policymaking.

details.title: Audio Visual Section
details.content: The Audio-Visual Section produces video, visual, and multimedia content for outreach, documentation, and education.

details.title: Tibet TV
details.content:
Official Website: https://www.tibetonline.tv/ 

Tibet TV is the official audiovisual media platform of the Department of Information and International Relations (DIIR) of the Central Tibetan Administration. Its primary role is to produce and disseminate video-based news, documentaries, interviews, educational programs, and special features related to Tibet, Tibetan governance, culture, and the Tibetan freedom movement. Tibet TV serves both Tibetan-speaking and international audiences by creating content in Tibetan and other languages, helping bridge the gap between the Tibetan community and the global public. Through digital platforms such as television broadcasts, YouTube, and social media, Tibet TV plays a crucial role in shaping narratives, preserving historical memory, amplifying Tibetan voices, and countering misinformation with factual, first-hand reporting.

details.title: Tibet Museum
details.content:
Official Website: https://tibetmuseum.org/ 

The Tibet Museum is an educational and historical institution under DIIR dedicated to documenting, preserving, and presenting the modern history of Tibet and the Tibetan exile experience. Through permanent and temporary exhibitions, archival materials, photographs, videos, and interactive displays, the museum provides visitors with a comprehensive understanding of Tibet’s political history, cultural heritage, and the impact of Chinese policies in Tibet. Located in Dharamshala, the Tibet Museum serves as a key space for public education, awareness-building, and dialogue, welcoming students, researchers, diplomats, tourists, and Tibet supporters from around the world. It plays an important role in ensuring that the Tibetan narrative is preserved, accurately represented, and passed on to future generations.

subsections.title: Translation, Publication & Media
subsections.content: This section handles translation of official documents, statements, and publications into multiple languages, ensuring consistent messaging across global audiences. The Media Coordination Desk manages relations with journalists and media organizations, with a Press Officer coordinating press briefings, media queries, and official communications with national and international media.

subsections.title: International Relations Section
subsections.content: The International Relations Section manages diplomatic outreach and engagement with governments, parliaments, international institutions, and civil society. DIIR oversees Offices of Tibet across the world, which function as de facto diplomatic missions representing His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the CTA.

details.title: New Delhi
details.content: Bureau of His Holiness the Dalai Lama

details.title: Kathmandu
details.content: Tibetan Refugee Welfare Office

details.title: Geneva
details.content: The Tibet Bureau

details.title: Washington DC
details.content: The Office of Tibet

details.title: Tokyo
details.content: Liaison Office of His Holiness the Dalai Lama

details.title: London

details.title: Brussels

details.title: Canberra
details.content: Tibet Information Office

details.title: Moscow
details.content: Tibet Culture and Information Center

details.title: Taipei

details.title: Pretoria
details.content: The Office of Tibet

details.title: São Paulo
details.content: Tibet House

details.title: Paris
details.content: Bureau du Tibet (under Brussels)

subsections.title: International Advocacy Desks
subsections.content: The Tibet Support Group Desk coordinates with Tibet support groups, advocacy networks, and solidarity organizations around the world. The UN, EU and Human Rights Desk engages with international human rights mechanisms, including the United Nations and European Union, to raise Tibet-related concerns. The Protocol Section manages official visits, formal engagements, and diplomatic protocol related to CTA leadership and international guests.

subsections.title: Narthang Press
subsections.content: Narthang Press is the official publishing arm of the Department of Information and International Relations of the Central Tibetan Administration. It is responsible for publishing books, policy documents, research reports, official statements, educational materials, and historical texts related to Tibet, Tibetan governance, culture, and the freedom movement. Narthang Press plays a vital role in preserving Tibetan intellectual heritage while also ensuring that accurate, authoritative information about Tibet reaches scholars, policymakers, and the general public. Through its publications in Tibetan, English, and other languages, Narthang Press supports informed discourse, documentation of the Tibetan struggle, and long-term knowledge preservation.

subsections.title: Tibet Policy Institute (TPI)
subsections.content:
Official Website: https://tibetpolicy.net/ 

The Tibet Policy Institute (TPI) is the research and policy think tank under DIIR. Its core mandate is to conduct independent, evidence-based research and policy analysis on issues related to Tibet, including politics, governance, human rights, environment, China-Tibet relations, and international affairs. TPI provides analytical support to CTA leadership and DIIR, helping inform advocacy strategies, diplomatic engagement, and public communication. Through research papers, briefings, seminars, and publications, TPI contributes to shaping informed global understanding of Tibet and strengthens the intellectual foundation of Tibetan policy and advocacy work.

departments.title: Department of Health
departments.content: The Department of Health is responsible for safeguarding the physical and mental health of Tibetans in exile. Operating under the Kashag of the Central Tibetan Administration, the department plans, coordinates, and oversees healthcare services across Tibetan settlements in India, Nepal, and Bhutan. Its work combines modern medical services and traditional Tibetan medicine, ensuring accessible, affordable, and culturally appropriate healthcare for the community.

subsections.title: Administration
subsections.content: The Administration Section manages the overall functioning of the Department of Health, including policy coordination, staffing, financial oversight, and liaison with affiliated institutions and settlement-level health facilities.

subsections.title: Projects
subsections.content: The Projects Section designs and implements health-related programs focused on preventive care, public health awareness, maternal and child health, disease prevention, mental health, and community well-being. These projects often work in collaboration with partner organizations and donors.

subsections.title: Affiliated Organisations
subsections.content: The Department of Health oversees and coordinates with several key health and medical institutions:

details.title: Delek Hospital
details.content: A major hospital in Dharamshala providing modern medical services to Tibetans and others.

details.title: Men-Tsee-Khang (Tibetan Medical & Astro Institute)
details.content: Preserves and practices traditional Tibetan medicine and astrology, with clinics across settlements.

details.title: Ngoenga School
details.content: Provides specialized education and care for children with special needs.

details.title: Central Council of Tibetan Medicine
details.content: Regulates and promotes standards in Tibetan medical practice.

subsections.title: Health Centers
subsections.content: The department manages a network of health facilities to ensure basic healthcare access across settlements:

details.title: Hospitals and PHCs
details.content: 12 Hospitals and Primary Health Centers (PHCs) providing comprehensive medical care.

details.title: Clinics
details.content: 33 Clinics offering localized health services.

details.title: Mobile Clinic
details.content: 1 Mobile Clinic, which serves remote and hard-to-reach areas.

subsections.title: Tibetan National Sports Association (TNSA)
subsections.content: The Tibetan National Sports Association (TNSA) functions under the Department of Health of the Central Tibetan Administration and is responsible for promoting sports, physical fitness, and healthy lifestyles among Tibetans in exile. TNSA organizes and coordinates sporting activities, tournaments, and training programs across Tibetan settlements, with a strong focus on youth engagement. Beyond physical health, TNSA views sports as a tool for discipline, teamwork, leadership development, and community cohesion. It also plays an important role in fostering national identity and unity by bringing together Tibetan youth from different regions through sports events, while encouraging lifelong habits of physical activity and well-being.

cta_structure.title: Autonomous Bodies
cta_structure.short_description: Independent institutions ensuring democratic integrity and accountability within the CTA.
cta_structure.long_description: Autonomous Bodies are constitutionally independent institutions that function separately from the executive branch (Kashag). Their independence ensures free elections, a professional civil service, and financial accountability, which are core pillars of Tibetan democracy in exile.

subsections.title: Appointment of Heads of the Autonomous Bodies
subsections.content:
The Presidents / Heads of the three Autonomous Bodies — the Election Commission, the Public Service Commission, and the Office of the Auditor General — are elected by the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile. This process ensures that these bodies remain independent of the executive branch (Kashag) while still being democratically accountable to the elected legislature.

By vesting the power of election in the Parliament, the Tibetan democratic system strengthens institutional independence, checks and balances, and public trust. Once elected, the heads of these bodies function autonomously and are expected to carry out their duties impartially, without political interference.

subsections.title: Election Commission
subsections.content:
The Election Commission is responsible for conducting free, fair, and transparent elections for all major Tibetan democratic institutions. This includes elections for the Sikyong, Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, and Local Tibetan Assemblies.

The Commission prepares electoral rules, manages voter registration, oversees nomination processes, conducts polling, and declares results. It also addresses electoral complaints and disputes to ensure credibility and public trust in the democratic process. By operating independently from political influence, the Election Commission safeguards the legitimacy of Tibetan self-governance and democratic continuity in exile.

subsections.title: Public Service Commission (PSC)
subsections.content:
The Public Service Commission (PSC) is responsible for the recruitment, examination, and appointment of civil servants within the CTA. Its primary mandate is to ensure that CTA staffing is based on merit, fairness, and transparency, rather than political influence or favoritism.

The PSC conducts competitive examinations, interviews, and selection processes for various grades of CTA service. It also advises on service rules, promotions, and disciplinary matters. By maintaining a professional and impartial civil service, the PSC strengthens institutional capacity and ensures continuity and efficiency in CTA administration.

subsections.title: Office of the Auditor General
subsections.content:
The Office of the Auditor General is the highest financial oversight authority of the CTA. Its role is to audit accounts, review financial management, and ensure accountability and transparency across all CTA departments, offices, and affiliated institutions.

The Auditor General examines whether public funds are used according to approved budgets, financial rules, and established procedures. Audit reports are submitted to the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, enabling legislative oversight of public spending. Through independent auditing and reporting, this office helps prevent misuse of funds, strengthens financial discipline, and builds public confidence in CTA institutions.
